title: UK travel firm Thomas Cook collapses
text:
A Thomas Cook aircraft at Manchester airport | Anthony Devlin/Getty Images UK travel firm Thomas Cook collapses The liquidation puts 9,000 British jobs in jeopardy and leaves 150,000 Brits stranded around the world.

U.K. travel firm Thomas Cook has gone into administration, leaving thousands of holidaymakers stranded overseas.

The liquidation puts 9,000 British jobs in jeopardy and leaves U.K. authorities on the hook to fly back to the country around 150,000 Brits left in the lurch around the world.

"Thomas Cook UK Plc and associated UK entities have entered Compulsory Liquidation and are now under the control of the Official Receiver," the firm's official website says. "A dedicated support service is being provided by The Civil Aviation Authority to assist customers currently overseas and those in the UK with future bookings."

The repatriation, dubbed "Operation Matterhorn" is the largest in the country's peacetime history, according to the Department for Transport. "The government and UK Civil Aviation Authority has hired dozens of charter planes to fly customers home free of charge. All customers currently abroad with Thomas Cook who are booked to return to the UK over the next 2 weeks will be brought home as close as possible to their booked return date," it said in a statement. According to the Guardian, the government is also relying on other British airlines such as Virgin and easyJet to ferry people home.

Speaking on his arrival in New York this morning for the U.N. General Assembly, British Prime Minister Boris Johnson promised the government would do its “level best” to get people home on time, and hinted at future measures to ensure travel company bosses do more to avoid financial risk.

“One is driven to reflect on whether the directors of these companies are properly incentivized to sort such matters out,” the PM said. He also revealed that the government had rejected a request from Thomas Cook for a bailout because doing so would have set up a “moral hazard,” Reuters reported.

Thomas Cook has struggled to cope with a £1.7 billion debt burden. An 11th-hour meeting on Sunday between company executives and stakeholders did not lead to a solution, according to the Guardian.

The collapse of Thomas Cook will also prove hugely costly to the U.K. taxpayer, with compensation payouts guaranteed to all customers who had booked holiday packages through the firm. Some estimates quoted by the Guardian put the total cost — including the mass repatriation — as high as £600 million.

However Transport Secretary Grant Shapps told BBC Radio 4's Today program this morning: "We know that the Monarch [Airlines] rescue was about £50 million, and we know that this is about 50 percent bigger. This is the biggest peacetime reparation, so it gives your a sort of indication [of the cost]."

He added that Thomas Cook had asked for a bailout of £250 million that the government had rejected in the early hours of the morning. "I fear it would have kept them [afloat] for a short period of time and then would have been back in the position to repatriate people in any case. The problems the company has are systemic."

Labour's Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell criticized the government response on the same show, saying the government should have stepped in to help, with "strings attached," following the “management failure” at the travel firm, owing to the thousands of jobs at risk and the threat to people's holidays.

This article has been updated.
description: The liquidation puts 9,000 British jobs in jeopardy and leaves 150,000 Brits stranded around the world.
